hints.label: def-episode-relabeling-group-discrete-sym
hints.title: Episode Relabeling Group
hints.content:
32: :label: def-episode-relabeling-group-discrete-sym
33: 
34: Let $\mathcal{E}$ be the set of all episodes generated by the Adaptive Gas algorithm. The **episode relabeling group** is:
35: 
36: $$
37: G_{\text{epi}} = \{\sigma : \mathcal{E} \to \mathcal{E} \mid \sigma \text{ is a bijection}\}
38: $$
39: 
40: This is the **symmetric group** on $\mathcal{E}$:
41: 
42: $$
43: G_{\text{epi}} \cong S_{|\mathcal{E}|}
44: $$
45: 
46: **Action on Fractal Set structures**:
47: 
48: 1. **CST edges**: $\sigma(e_i \to e_j) := \sigma(e_i) \to \sigma(e_j)$
49: 2. **IG edges**: $\sigma(e_i \sim e_j) := \sigma(e_i) \sim \sigma(e_j)$
50: 3. **Episode durations**: $\tau_{\sigma(e)} = \tau_e$ (intrinsic property)
51: 4. **Spatial embedding**: $\Phi(\sigma(e)) = \Phi(e)$ (canonical choice: death position)
hints.raw_directive:
29: ### 1.1. Episode Permutation Group $S_{|\mathcal{E}|}$
30: 
31: :::{prf:definition} Episode Relabeling Group
32: :label: def-episode-relabeling-group-discrete-sym
33: 
34: Let $\mathcal{E}$ be the set of all episodes generated by the Adaptive Gas algorithm. The **episode relabeling group** is:
35: 
36: $$
37: G_{\text{epi}} = \{\sigma : \mathcal{E} \to \mathcal{E} \mid \sigma \text{ is a bijection}\}
38: $$
39: 
40: This is the **symmetric group** on $\mathcal{E}$:
41: 
42: $$
43: G_{\text{epi}} \cong S_{|\mathcal{E}|}
44: $$
45: 
46: **Action on Fractal Set structures**:
47: 
48: 1. **CST edges**: $\sigma(e_i \to e_j) := \sigma(e_i) \to \sigma(e_j)$
49: 2. **IG edges**: $\sigma(e_i \sim e_j) := \sigma(e_i) \sim \sigma(e_j)$
50: 3. **Episode durations**: $\tau_{\sigma(e)} = \tau_e$ (intrinsic property)
51: 4. **Spatial embedding**: $\Phi(\sigma(e)) = \Phi(e)$ (canonical choice: death position)
52:

hints.label: unlabeled-remark-28
hints.title: Gauge Degrees of Freedom
hints.content:
57: :class: note
58: 
59: The episode permutation group $S_{|\mathcal{E}|}$ represents **gauge degrees of freedom** at the graph level:
60: - Episode identifiers are **unphysical** (assigned by algorithmic bookkeeping)
61: - All physical observables must be **permutation-invariant**
62: - This mirrors walker permutation symmetry $S_N$ at the swarm level (Chapter 9, Theorem 9.2.1)
63: 
64: Contrast with:
hints.raw_directive:
54: :::
55: 
56: :::{prf:remark} Gauge Degrees of Freedom
57: :class: note
58: 
59: The episode permutation group $S_{|\mathcal{E}|}$ represents **gauge degrees of freedom** at the graph level:
60: - Episode identifiers are **unphysical** (assigned by algorithmic bookkeeping)
61: - All physical observables must be **permutation-invariant**
62: - This mirrors walker permutation symmetry $S_N$ at the swarm level (Chapter 9, Theorem 9.2.1)
63: 
64: Contrast with:
65: - **Continuous gauge theories**: Local gauge transformations act on internal quantum numbers (e.g., U(1) phase, SU(2) isospin)

hints.label: thm-discrete-permutation-invariance-discrete-sym
hints.title: Discrete Permutation Invariance
hints.content:
72: :label: thm-discrete-permutation-invariance-discrete-sym
73: 
74: The Fractal Set $\mathcal{F} = (\mathcal{E}, E_{\text{CST}} \cup E_{\text{IG}})$ is **statistically invariant** under episode relabeling.
75: 
76: **Precise statement**: For any bijection $\sigma : \mathcal{E} \to \mathcal{E}$ and any graph-theoretic functional $F : \mathcal{F} \to \mathbb{R}$,
77: 
78: $$
79: \mathbb{E}[F(\mathcal{F})] = \mathbb{E}[F(\sigma(\mathcal{F}))]
80: $$
81: 
82: where $\sigma(\mathcal{F}) = (\sigma(\mathcal{E}), \{\sigma(e_i) \to \sigma(e_j) : e_i \to e_j \in E_{\text{CST}}\} \cup \{\sigma(e_i) \sim \sigma(e_j) : e_i \sim e_j \in E_{\text{IG}}\})$.
83: 
84: **Graph isomorphism**: The relabeled Fractal Set is isomorphic to the original:
85: 
86: $$
87: \sigma(\mathcal{F}) \cong \mathcal{F}
88: $$
hints.raw_directive:
69: ### 1.2. Permutation Invariance Theorem
70: 
71: :::{prf:theorem} Discrete Permutation Invariance
72: :label: thm-discrete-permutation-invariance-discrete-sym
73: 
74: The Fractal Set $\mathcal{F} = (\mathcal{E}, E_{\text{CST}} \cup E_{\text{IG}})$ is **statistically invariant** under episode relabeling.
75: 
76: **Precise statement**: For any bijection $\sigma : \mathcal{E} \to \mathcal{E}$ and any graph-theoretic functional $F : \mathcal{F} \to \mathbb{R}$,
77: 
78: $$
79: \mathbb{E}[F(\mathcal{F})] = \mathbb{E}[F(\sigma(\mathcal{F}))]
80: $$
81: 
82: where $\sigma(\mathcal{F}) = (\sigma(\mathcal{E}), \{\sigma(e_i) \to \sigma(e_j) : e_i \to e_j \in E_{\text{CST}}\} \cup \{\sigma(e_i) \sim \sigma(e_j) : e_i \sim e_j \in E_{\text{IG}}\})$.
83: 
84: **Graph isomorphism**: The relabeled Fractal Set is isomorphic to the original:
85: 
86: $$
87: \sigma(\mathcal{F}) \cong \mathcal{F}
88: $$
89:

hints.label: unlabeled-proof-65
hints.content:
92: 
93: :::{prf:proof}
94: We verify invariance at each stage of the Fractal Set construction.
95: 
96: **Step 1: CST construction is label-independent**
97: 
98: The parent-child relation $e_i \to e_j$ is defined by:
99: 
100: $$
101: t^{\rm b}_j = t^{\rm d}_i \quad \text{and} \quad \text{parent}(e_j) = \text{id}(e_i)
102: $$
103: 
104: Under relabeling $\sigma$:
105: - Birth times: $t^{\rm b}_{\sigma(e_j)} = t^{\rm b}_j$ (intrinsic to episode)
106: - Death times: $t^{\rm d}_{\sigma(e_i)} = t^{\rm d}_i$ (intrinsic to episode)
107: - Parent function: $\text{parent}(\sigma(e_j)) = \sigma(\text{parent}(e_j))$ (relabel preserves genealogy)
108: 
109: Therefore:
110: 
111: $$
112: e_i \to e_j \iff \sigma(e_i) \to \sigma(e_j)
113: $$
114: 
115: The CST edge set is preserved: $\sigma(E_{\text{CST}}) = E_{\text{CST}}$ up to relabeling.
116: 
117: **Step 2: IG construction is label-independent**
118: 
119: IG edges are created by **selection coupling**: $e_i \sim e_j$ if episodes $i$ and $j$ were both alive during a cloning event.
120: 
121: The alive set at time $t$ is:
122: 
123: $$
124: \mathcal{A}(t) = \{e \in \mathcal{E} : t^{\rm b}_e \leq t < t^{\rm d}_e\}
125: $$
126: 
127: Under relabeling $\sigma$:
128: 
129: $$
130: \sigma(\mathcal{A}(t)) = \{\sigma(e) : e \in \mathcal{A}(t)\} = \mathcal{A}(t)
131: $$
132: 
133: (as sets, since bijections preserve set equality).
134: 
135: The IG edge relation is:
136: 
137: $$
138: e_i \sim e_j \iff \exists t : e_i, e_j \in \mathcal{A}(t)
139: $$
140: 
141: Applying $\sigma$:
142: 
143: $$
144: \sigma(e_i) \sim \sigma(e_j) \iff \exists t : \sigma(e_i), \sigma(e_j) \in \sigma(\mathcal{A}(t)) = \mathcal{A}(t)
145: $$
146: 
147: Therefore $\sigma(E_{\text{IG}}) = E_{\text{IG}}$ up to relabeling.
148: 
149: **Step 3: Graph functionals are invariant**
150: 
151: Any graph-theoretic functional $F : \mathcal{F} \to \mathbb{R}$ that depends only on:
152: - Vertex connectivity (which episodes connect)
153: - Edge weights (functions of episode properties)
154: - Graph topology (paths, cycles, components)
155: 
156: is invariant under relabeling:
157: 
158: $$
159: F(\sigma(\mathcal{F})) = F(\mathcal{F})
160: $$
161: 
162: Taking expectation over randomness in the algorithm:
163: 
164: $$
165: \mathbb{E}[F(\mathcal{F})] = \mathbb{E}[F(\sigma(\mathcal{F}))]
166: $$
hints.raw_directive:
91: :::
92: 
93: :::{prf:proof}
94: We verify invariance at each stage of the Fractal Set construction.
95: 
96: **Step 1: CST construction is label-independent**
97: 
98: The parent-child relation $e_i \to e_j$ is defined by:
99: 
100: $$
101: t^{\rm b}_j = t^{\rm d}_i \quad \text{and} \quad \text{parent}(e_j) = \text{id}(e_i)
102: $$
103: 
104: Under relabeling $\sigma$:
105: - Birth times: $t^{\rm b}_{\sigma(e_j)} = t^{\rm b}_j$ (intrinsic to episode)
106: - Death times: $t^{\rm d}_{\sigma(e_i)} = t^{\rm d}_i$ (intrinsic to episode)
107: - Parent function: $\text{parent}(\sigma(e_j)) = \sigma(\text{parent}(e_j))$ (relabel preserves genealogy)
108: 
109: Therefore:
110: 
111: $$
112: e_i \to e_j \iff \sigma(e_i) \to \sigma(e_j)
113: $$
114: 
115: The CST edge set is preserved: $\sigma(E_{\text{CST}}) = E_{\text{CST}}$ up to relabeling.
116: 
117: **Step 2: IG construction is label-independent**
118: 
119: IG edges are created by **selection coupling**: $e_i \sim e_j$ if episodes $i$ and $j$ were both alive during a cloning event.
120: 
121: The alive set at time $t$ is:
122: 
123: $$
124: \mathcal{A}(t) = \{e \in \mathcal{E} : t^{\rm b}_e \leq t < t^{\rm d}_e\}
125: $$
126: 
127: Under relabeling $\sigma$:
128: 
129: $$
130: \sigma(\mathcal{A}(t)) = \{\sigma(e) : e \in \mathcal{A}(t)\} = \mathcal{A}(t)
131: $$
132: 
133: (as sets, since bijections preserve set equality).
134: 
135: The IG edge relation is:
136: 
137: $$
138: e_i \sim e_j \iff \exists t : e_i, e_j \in \mathcal{A}(t)
139: $$
140: 
141: Applying $\sigma$:
142: 
143: $$
144: \sigma(e_i) \sim \sigma(e_j) \iff \exists t : \sigma(e_i), \sigma(e_j) \in \sigma(\mathcal{A}(t)) = \mathcal{A}(t)
145: $$
146: 
147: Therefore $\sigma(E_{\text{IG}}) = E_{\text{IG}}$ up to relabeling.
148: 
149: **Step 3: Graph functionals are invariant**
150: 
151: Any graph-theoretic functional $F : \mathcal{F} \to \mathbb{R}$ that depends only on:
152: - Vertex connectivity (which episodes connect)
153: - Edge weights (functions of episode properties)
154: - Graph topology (paths, cycles, components)
155: 
156: is invariant under relabeling:
157: 
158: $$
159: F(\sigma(\mathcal{F})) = F(\mathcal{F})
160: $$
161: 
162: Taking expectation over randomness in the algorithm:
163: 
164: $$
165: \mathbb{E}[F(\mathcal{F})] = \mathbb{E}[F(\sigma(\mathcal{F}))]
166: $$
167:

hints.label: cor-continuous-limit-permutation-discrete-sym
hints.title: Continuous Limit Recovers Swarm Permutation Symmetry
hints.content:
172: :label: cor-continuous-limit-permutation-discrete-sym
173: 
174: In the limit $N \to \infty$, the episode relabeling symmetry $G_{\text{epi}} \cong S_{|\mathcal{E}|}$ converges to the **walker permutation symmetry** $S_N$ from Chapter 9.
175: 
176: The episode permutation group $S_{|\mathcal{E}_N|}$ restricts to $S_N$ via the **walker projection map**:
177: 
178: $$
179: \pi : S_{|\mathcal{E}_N|} \to S_N, \quad \sigma \mapsto \tilde{\sigma}
180: $$
181: 
182: where $\tilde{\sigma}(i) = j$ if $\sigma$ maps the current episode of walker $i$ to the current episode of walker $j$.
183: 
184: **Convergence**: For functionals $F$ that factor through walker indices,
185: 
186: $$
187: \lim_{N \to \infty} \mathbb{E}[F(\mathcal{F}_N)] = \mathbb{E}[F(\text{swarm configuration})]
188: $$
hints.raw_directive:
169: :::
170: 
171: :::{prf:corollary} Continuous Limit Recovers Swarm Permutation Symmetry
172: :label: cor-continuous-limit-permutation-discrete-sym
173: 
174: In the limit $N \to \infty$, the episode relabeling symmetry $G_{\text{epi}} \cong S_{|\mathcal{E}|}$ converges to the **walker permutation symmetry** $S_N$ from Chapter 9.
175: 
176: The episode permutation group $S_{|\mathcal{E}_N|}$ restricts to $S_N$ via the **walker projection map**:
177: 
178: $$
179: \pi : S_{|\mathcal{E}_N|} \to S_N, \quad \sigma \mapsto \tilde{\sigma}
180: $$
181: 
182: where $\tilde{\sigma}(i) = j$ if $\sigma$ maps the current episode of walker $i$ to the current episode of walker $j$.
183: 
184: **Convergence**: For functionals $F$ that factor through walker indices,
185: 
186: $$
187: \lim_{N \to \infty} \mathbb{E}[F(\mathcal{F}_N)] = \mathbb{E}[F(\text{swarm configuration})]
188: $$
189:

hints.label: unlabeled-remark-165
hints.title: Permutation Symmetry Breaking via Episode Identifiers
hints.content:
194: :class: warning
195: 
196: While the Fractal Set **structure** is permutation-invariant, specific algorithmic implementations may introduce **artificial symmetry breaking** through:
197: 
198: 1. **Chronological ordering**: Episodes created earlier receive lower ID numbers
199: 2. **Walker persistence**: Episode IDs correlate with walker IDs (which persist across cloning events)
200: 3. **Hash-based identifiers**: Deterministic but non-exchangeable ID assignment
201: 
202: **Consequence**: Numerical simulations must verify permutation invariance explicitly by:
203: - Testing functionals under random relabelings $\sigma \in S_{|\mathcal{E}|}$
hints.raw_directive:
191: :::
192: 
193: :::{prf:remark} Permutation Symmetry Breaking via Episode Identifiers
194: :class: warning
195: 
196: While the Fractal Set **structure** is permutation-invariant, specific algorithmic implementations may introduce **artificial symmetry breaking** through:
197: 
198: 1. **Chronological ordering**: Episodes created earlier receive lower ID numbers
199: 2. **Walker persistence**: Episode IDs correlate with walker IDs (which persist across cloning events)
200: 3. **Hash-based identifiers**: Deterministic but non-exchangeable ID assignment
201: 
202: **Consequence**: Numerical simulations must verify permutation invariance explicitly by:
203: - Testing functionals under random relabelings $\sigma \in S_{|\mathcal{E}|}$
204: - Using canonical orderings (e.g., sorted by birth time) for reproducibility

hints.label: def-spatial-transformation-fractal-set-discrete-sym
hints.title: Spatial Transformation of Fractal Set
hints.content:
211: :label: def-spatial-transformation-fractal-set-discrete-sym
212: 
213: For a spatial transformation $\Psi : \mathcal{X} \to \mathcal{X}$ (e.g., translation $T_a$, rotation $R \in SO(d)$), define the **push-forward** on the Fractal Set:
214: 
215: $$
216: \Psi_*(\mathcal{F}) = (\mathcal{E}, E_{\text{CST}} \cup E_{\text{IG}}, \Psi \circ \Phi)
217: $$
218: 
219: where:
220: - Episodes $\mathcal{E}$ are unchanged (graph vertices)
221: - CST/IG edges are unchanged (genealogy is spatial-transformation-invariant)
222: - Spatial embedding is transformed: $\Phi(e) \mapsto \Psi(\Phi(e))$
223: 
224: **Functional transformation**: For functionals $F[\mathcal{F}]$ depending on spatial positions:
225: 
226: $$
hints.raw_directive:
208: ### 1.3. Spatial Transformation Symmetries
209: 
210: :::{prf:definition} Spatial Transformation of Fractal Set
211: :label: def-spatial-transformation-fractal-set-discrete-sym
212: 
213: For a spatial transformation $\Psi : \mathcal{X} \to \mathcal{X}$ (e.g., translation $T_a$, rotation $R \in SO(d)$), define the **push-forward** on the Fractal Set:
214: 
215: $$
216: \Psi_*(\mathcal{F}) = (\mathcal{E}, E_{\text{CST}} \cup E_{\text{IG}}, \Psi \circ \Phi)
217: $$
218: 
219: where:
220: - Episodes $\mathcal{E}$ are unchanged (graph vertices)
221: - CST/IG edges are unchanged (genealogy is spatial-transformation-invariant)
222: - Spatial embedding is transformed: $\Phi(e) \mapsto \Psi(\Phi(e))$
223: 
224: **Functional transformation**: For functionals $F[\mathcal{F}]$ depending on spatial positions:
225: 
226: $$
227: (\Psi_* F)[\mathcal{F}] = F[\Psi_*(\mathcal{F})]

hints.label: thm-discrete-translation-equivariance-discrete-sym
hints.title: Discrete Translation Equivariance
hints.content:
232: :label: thm-discrete-translation-equivariance-discrete-sym
233: 
234: Suppose the reward function $R(x, v)$ and valid domain $\mathcal{X}_{\text{valid}}$ satisfy:
235: 
236: $$
237: R(x + a, v) = R(x, v), \quad x + a \in \mathcal{X}_{\text{valid}} \iff x \in \mathcal{X}_{\text{valid}}
238: $$
239: 
240: for some $a \in \mathbb{R}^d$ (translation symmetry of the environment).
241: 
242: Then the Fractal Set distribution is **translation-equivariant**:
243: 
244: $$
245: \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{F}) = \mathcal{L}(T_a(\mathcal{F}))
246: $$
247: 
248: **Graph structure preservation**: The CST and IG edge sets are **invariant** under translation:
249: 
250: $$
251: E_{\text{CST}}[T_a(\mathcal{F})] = E_{\text{CST}}[\mathcal{F}], \quad E_{\text{IG}}[T_a(\mathcal{F})] = E_{\text{IG}}[\mathcal{F}]
252: $$
hints.raw_directive:
229: :::
230: 
231: :::{prf:theorem} Discrete Translation Equivariance
232: :label: thm-discrete-translation-equivariance-discrete-sym
233: 
234: Suppose the reward function $R(x, v)$ and valid domain $\mathcal{X}_{\text{valid}}$ satisfy:
235: 
236: $$
237: R(x + a, v) = R(x, v), \quad x + a \in \mathcal{X}_{\text{valid}} \iff x \in \mathcal{X}_{\text{valid}}
238: $$
239: 
240: for some $a \in \mathbb{R}^d$ (translation symmetry of the environment).
241: 
242: Then the Fractal Set distribution is **translation-equivariant**:
243: 
244: $$
245: \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{F}) = \mathcal{L}(T_a(\mathcal{F}))
246: $$
247: 
248: **Graph structure preservation**: The CST and IG edge sets are **invariant** under translation:
249: 
250: $$
251: E_{\text{CST}}[T_a(\mathcal{F})] = E_{\text{CST}}[\mathcal{F}], \quad E_{\text{IG}}[T_a(\mathcal{F})] = E_{\text{IG}}[\mathcal{F}]
252: $$
253:

hints.label: unlabeled-proof-229
hints.content:
256: 
257: :::{prf:proof}
258: **Step 1: Cloning mechanism is translation-invariant**
259: 
260: The cloning probability depends on:
261: 
262: $$
263: P_{\text{clone}}(e) = f(\Phi_{\text{fit}}(x_e, v_e, S_t))
264: $$
265: 
266: Under translation $x \mapsto x + a$:
267: - Reward: $R(x + a, v) = R(x, v)$ by assumption
268: - Algorithmic distances: $d_{\text{alg}}((x_i + a, v_i), (x_j + a, v_j)) = d_{\text{alg}}((x_i, v_i), (x_j, v_j))$
269: - Fitness potential: $\Phi_{\text{fit}}(x + a, v, S_t) = \Phi_{\text{fit}}(x, v, T_a(S_t))$
270: 
271: Therefore, cloning decisions are statistically equivalent.
272: 
273: **Step 2: CST construction is translation-equivariant**
274: 
275: The parent-child relation depends only on **time**:
276: 
277: $$
278: e_i \to e_j \iff t^{\rm b}_j = t^{\rm d}_i
279: $$
280: 
281: Translation does not affect time coordinates, so $E_{\text{CST}}[T_a(\mathcal{F})] = E_{\text{CST}}[\mathcal{F}]$.
282: 
283: **Step 3: IG construction is translation-equivariant**
284: 
285: The IG edge relation $e_i \sim e_j$ is defined by **temporal overlap**:
286: 
287: $$
288: e_i \sim e_j \iff \exists t : e_i, e_j \in \mathcal{A}(t)
289: $$
290: 
291: The alive set depends on birth/death times, invariant under spatial translation.
hints.raw_directive:
255: :::
256: 
257: :::{prf:proof}
258: **Step 1: Cloning mechanism is translation-invariant**
259: 
260: The cloning probability depends on:
261: 
262: $$
263: P_{\text{clone}}(e) = f(\Phi_{\text{fit}}(x_e, v_e, S_t))
264: $$
265: 
266: Under translation $x \mapsto x + a$:
267: - Reward: $R(x + a, v) = R(x, v)$ by assumption
268: - Algorithmic distances: $d_{\text{alg}}((x_i + a, v_i), (x_j + a, v_j)) = d_{\text{alg}}((x_i, v_i), (x_j, v_j))$
269: - Fitness potential: $\Phi_{\text{fit}}(x + a, v, S_t) = \Phi_{\text{fit}}(x, v, T_a(S_t))$
270: 
271: Therefore, cloning decisions are statistically equivalent.
272: 
273: **Step 2: CST construction is translation-equivariant**
274: 
275: The parent-child relation depends only on **time**:
276: 
277: $$
278: e_i \to e_j \iff t^{\rm b}_j = t^{\rm d}_i
279: $$
280: 
281: Translation does not affect time coordinates, so $E_{\text{CST}}[T_a(\mathcal{F})] = E_{\text{CST}}[\mathcal{F}]$.
282: 
283: **Step 3: IG construction is translation-equivariant**
284: 
285: The IG edge relation $e_i \sim e_j$ is defined by **temporal overlap**:
286: 
287: $$
288: e_i \sim e_j \iff \exists t : e_i, e_j \in \mathcal{A}(t)
289: $$
290: 
291: The alive set depends on birth/death times, invariant under spatial translation.
292:

hints.label: cor-discrete-rotational-equivariance-discrete-sym
hints.title: Rotational Equivariance
hints.content:
297: :label: cor-discrete-rotational-equivariance-discrete-sym
298: 
299: For rotationally symmetric reward $R(Rx, Rv) = R(x, v)$ and domain ($R \in SO(d)$), the Fractal Set is rotationally equivariant:
300: 
301: $$
302: \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{F}) = \mathcal{L}(R_*(\mathcal{F}))
303: $$
hints.raw_directive:
294: :::
295: 
296: :::{prf:corollary} Rotational Equivariance
297: :label: cor-discrete-rotational-equivariance-discrete-sym
298: 
299: For rotationally symmetric reward $R(Rx, Rv) = R(x, v)$ and domain ($R \in SO(d)$), the Fractal Set is rotationally equivariant:
300: 
301: $$
302: \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{F}) = \mathcal{L}(R_*(\mathcal{F}))
303: $$
304:
